metadata.title: A ‘Barn Find’ GT350H Hidden In Plain View | Motorious.com
metadata.description: Is this special edition Mustang worth salvaging?
metadata.author: Elizabeth Puckett Feb 12, 2020

metadata.title: This DeLorean Barn Find Finally Sees Daylight After 32 Years | Motorious.com
metadata.description: The car was parked in the barn back in 1986.
metadata.author: Amie Williams

sections: It sat for so long it sunk partway into the ground.
are exciting things people always want to hear about, but this story of a 1966

which was found in a backyard in Ohio is just as interesting as any barn find, if not more so. To start, it sat in that yard since the early 1980s, so around four decades, and somehow isn’t a pile of rust. The poor classic
sunk partway into the ground and certain parts of it are about as brittle as graham cracker, but it survived harsh winters and hot summers alike for all those years.
out of its sunken resting spot, it required a lawyer to draft up legal documents absolving the tow truck company and rescue team of responsibility if the

were to fall apart. She sure doesn’t look pretty, with plenty of crackling and bubbling paint. Still, you can clearly see the Raven Black with those iconic gold stripes, so it’s clear to even a casual enthusiast what it is.

The process of rescuing this car has been slow, as is so often the case. The guy who originally found it first got a glimpse after following wild stories back in April of 2015. Through negotiations they finally were able to move on the car, which is largely original but certainly needs a comprehensive restoration.

Naturally, the big question to ask is if rescuing the car is worth all this effort? It might seem ridiculous, but current average values are almost $130,000. So even if they sink $80,000 into restoring the car and get an average return, it’s a cool $50,000 net profit. What would you do to earn $50,000?
This amazing video and story comes via
. He’s a freelance automotive journalist and has a knack for these unique vehicle finds.
